docs.lead_paragraph: Unemployment surged in New York City last month, as job losses hit hard on Wall Street and in some of the other industries that economists say will be most hurt by the destruction of the World Trade Center. New data from the New York State Labor Department and the New York City comptroller's office paint a picture of an economy that was rapidly weakening in August, even before the trade center disaster last week.

headline.main: New Data Show Rapid Decline In Employment Last Month

docs.abstract: Unemployment surged in New York City in August, as job losses hit hard on Wall Street and in some other industries that economists say will be most hurt by destruction of World Trade Center; unemployment rate is at 5.8 percent in Aug, highest jobless rate since May 2000 (M)
docs.snippet: Unemployment surged in New York City last month, as job losses hit hard on Wall Street and in some of the other industries that economists say will be most hurt by the destruction of the World Trade Center.    New data from the New York State Labor...

docs.lead_paragraph: New York's largest janitors' union and the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations reached an agreement yesterday to help the 2,000 janitors, elevator operators and security guards who lost jobs because of the World Trade Center attacks. The realty board and the union, Local 32B-32J of the Service Employees International Union, agreed to provide the workers with health insurance and supplemental unemployment insurance equal to 80 percent of their gross pay for six months. Several dozen cleaning contractors also agreed to give preference to those janitors in future hiring. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Aid For Trade Center Janitors

docs.abstract: Service Employees International Union and New York realty board reach agreement on helping 2,000 janitors, elevators operators and security guards who lost jobs because of World Trade Center attack (S)

byline.original: By Steven Greenhouse (NYT) (Compiled by Anthony Ramirez)

docs.lead_paragraph: David Emil, the president of the company that ran Windows on the World, the beloved restaurant at the World Trade Center, stood before a sea of faces -- busboys from Ecuador, dishwashers from Ghana, cooks from Bangladesh -- and offered them a smidgen of hope. Someday, he said, not next year, but certainly in five years or six, he will open a new Windows on the World.

headline.main: A Showpiece's Survivors Wonder What to Do Now
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: WINDOWS ON THE WORLD

docs.abstract: David Emil, president of company that ran Windows on the World, restaurant atop World Trade Center, addresses employees who survived terrorist attack and promises them restaurant will reopen at some point; relatives and survivors face immediate problems of providing support to their families; photo (M)
docs.snippet: David Emil, the president of the company that ran Windows on the World, the beloved restaurant at the World Trade Center, stood before a sea of faces -- busboys from Ecuador, dishwashers from Ghana, cooks from Bangladesh -- and offered them a smidgen...

docs.lead_paragraph: LAST Thursday, when Mary Miss and her husband, George Peck, returned to their loft apartment near the disaster site, they took one look around and vowed to return the next day with reinforcements. The dust was thick and everywhere. Ms. Miss, 57, is an artist who does public art projects. She and Mr. Peck, 60, rounded up friends and armed themselves with masks, Windex, Murphy's Oil Soap, rubber gloves and rags. Then, for safety, they rolled down their sleeves.

headline.main: It's Going to Take More Than Elbow Grease

docs.abstract: Massive cleanup task faces residents of Lower Manhattan whose apartments were coated with dust that floated in open windows following collapse of World Trade Center; photo (M)
docs.snippet: LAST Thursday, when Mary Miss and her husband, George Peck, returned to their loft apartment near the disaster site, they took one look around and vowed to return the next day with reinforcements.    The dust was thick and everywhere. Ms. Miss, 57,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Although financial relief for survivors of those who died in the World Trade Center attack may total in the hundreds of millions of dollars, some families now stand to receive no more than $30,000 in direct aid, according to officials involved in government and private relief efforts. Across a vast landscape of need -- from those supported by dishwashers and bond traders, firefighters and security guards -- the flow of death benefits for survivors, so far, looks jaggedly uneven.

headline.main: Money for Families Of Attack Victims Could Vary Widely

docs.abstract: Flow of death benefits for survivors of those who died in World Trade Center attack looks jaggedly uneven; officials involved in government and private relief efforts say that while financial relief for survivors may total in hundreds of millions of dollars, some families now stand to receive no more than $30,000 in direct aid; millions in public and private funds are streaming to relief effort, with large parts of it channeled to unique categories of victims, like firefighters or children of airline passengers who may have fought with hijackers; there is also well-established net of benefits in place for families of uniformed workers who die in line of duty; at other end of spectrum, kitchen workers at Windows on the World have $15,000 life insurance policies, and their families' union health insurance will end in Nov; company that ran restaurant no longer exists, for any practical purpose, and cannot provide additional support (M)

byline.original: By JIM DWYER and DIANA B. HENRIQUES

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: Nearly 40,000 elderly people will have to change insurance plans by Jan. 1, when two more health maintenance organizations drop out of the state's Medicare program. The groups, ConnectiCare and MedSpan Health Options, said on Monday that they were leaving the state's Medicare market because of low reimbursements from the federal government. The pullouts leave elderly people in five Connecticut counties -- Litchfield, Middlesex, New London, Tolland and Windham -- without coverage from Medicare H.M.O.'s.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Health Care Groups Withdraw

docs.abstract: ConnectiCare and MedSpan Health Options to withdraw from Connecticut's Medicare program Jan 1, citing low federal reimbursements; moves affect nearly 40,000 elderly people and will leave five counties without any Medicare HMO coverage (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration approved an innovative Florida program today to lower prescription drug costs for people on Medicaid and Medicare. Under a new Florida law, signed in June by Gov. Jeb Bush, drug manufacturers must provide discounts if they want their products included on a list of preferred drugs for recipients of Medicaid, the joint federal-state health program for the poor.

headline.main: U.S. Backs Florida Plan to Cut Drug Costs

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. John Kitzhaber has appointed Jean Thorne, a longtime aide, to lead the proposed expansion of the Oregon Health Plan, which offers coverage to the poor and uninsured. The Legislature ordered the state to seek federal waivers to improve access to health care and to low-cost private insurance for children, the elderly and low-income residents. In her new role, Ms. Thorne, who currently advises the governor on education and work-force issues, will work to secure federal waivers to carry out the expansion. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 Ulster Catholic Leader Resigns from Party Post John Hume, a leader of the Catholic civil rights movement in Northern Ireland for the last 40 years, announced in Belfast that he was stepping down as head of the province's Social Democratic and Labor Party. Mr. Hume, who was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1998, said the timing of his resignation was dictated by his deteriorating health. A3

docs.lead_paragraph: THEY work all day. Then they work at night. Instead of enjoying spare time or just hunkering down in front of the television set, they pursue a second career. What's in it for these moonlighters? Not just the extra money. Pursuing a dual career is about passion and fulfilling dreams. The tradeoff: time. In Blues or Scrubs Dr. Nicholas Tumminello is a podiatrist who runs a full-time practice in Valley Stream. As a board-certified surgeon, he can often be found in the operating room at Franklin General Hospital. When he's not in his scrubs, he's in his blues. Dr. Tumminello, 36, of Barnum Island, has a second full-time career as a Nassau County police officer, assigned to the Fourth Precinct.

headline.main: Moonlighting Becomes You: It's the Love, Not the Money

docs.abstract: Article describes lives of several Long Islanders who work nights, including Dr Nicholas Tumminello, full-time podiatrist who is also full-time Nassau County police officer, insurance adjuster Rich Warkenthien, who is also stand-up comedian known as Rich Walker, Steve Broggi, truck driver by day who runs mobile bait and tackle business by night, Bonnie Graham, computer software company marketing director who produces and anchors public-access TV and radio talk shows, and Dr Scott Danoff, dentist who does woodworking at night; photos (L) (Special Issue: After 5)
